questions.text: Which of the following uses population as the unit of study?
questions.solution: Ecological study uses population as the unit of study.

questions.text: Statistical power of a test is equal to ______
questions.solution: The power of a trial is represented by 1 – β where β is type II error or false negative error.

questions.text: The standard illumination recommended for casual reading is _______ lux
questions.solution:
The standard illumination for casual reading is 100 lux.

Lighting Standards

The following standards have been recommended by the Illuminating Engineer Society.

Visual Task Illumination in lux
Casual reading 100
General office work 400
Fine assembly 900
Very severe tasks 1300 – 2000
Watch making 2000 – 3000

questions.text: Sequence of activities designed to implement policies and accomplish objectives is called
questions.solution:
A programme is a sequence of activities designed to implement policies and accomplish objectives.

Option a: Procedures are a set of rules for carrying out the work which helps to ensure maximum use of the resources and efforts.

Option b: A plan is a blueprint for taking action.

Option d: A schedule is a time sequence for the work to be done.

questions.text: False about a standard normal distribution curve is
questions.solution:
In a normal distribution curve, variance is 1.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: Denominator used for calculating incidence is
questions.solution:
Population at risk is the denominator for calculating incidence.

Incidence is defined as “the number of NEW cases occuring in a defined population during a specified period of time.”

It is given by the formula:

Incident Rate = Number of NEW cases of specific disease during given Time period / Population at risk during given Time period

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: What would be the degree of freedom if a contingency table had 8 rows and 6 columns?
questions.solution:
• In a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.
  • The above contingency table has 8 rows and 6 columns.
  • In this scenario, df = (8 – 1) (6 – 1) = 7*5 = 35.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a rural housing standard in India?

choices.text: Built-up area should not exceed 1/3rd of total area
Cattle sheds must be 25 feet away from the house

questions.solution:
Window area should be 10% of floor area.

Rural housing standards are:

  • At least two living rooms
  • Ample verandah space
  • Separate kitchen with space for washing utensils
  • Built-up area should not exceed 1/3rd of total area
  • Sanitary latrine
  • Window area should be 10% of floor area
  • Sanitary well or tube well within quarter mile of house
  • Cattle sheds must be 25 feet away from the house
  • Adequate arrangements for disposal of waste water and garbage

questions.text: False statement is

choices.text: Disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid
Horrock’s apparatus is used to estimate chlorine demand
Orthotolidine arsenite test measures free and combined chlorine separately

questions.solution:
Bleaching powder contains 33% available chlorine.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text:
Match the breeding habits of given mosquitoes
A.	Anopheles	I.	Dirty water
B.	Aedes	II. Clean water
C.	Culex	III. Aquatic vegetation
D.	Mansonia	IV. Artificial collection of water
questions.solution:
Breeding habits of mosquitoes:

 

Mosquito Breeding habit
Anopheles Clean water
Culex Dirty, polluted water
Aedes Artificial collection of water
Mansonia Aquatic vegetation

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a model of health education?
questions.solution:
Three models of health education:

  • Medical model: Transfer of proven medical information into education
  • Motivational model: Awareness → Motivation → Action or Internalization
  • Social intervention model: Changing of a social environment

questions.text: False statement about the type of epidemic represented in below given image is

choices.text: Clustering of cases within a short period of time
Only due to an infectious agent
All cases usually develop within one incubation period

questions.solution:
Image shows point source epidemic.

  • Point source epidemics are also called single exposure epidemics and belong to the common source type of epidemics.
  • The exposure to disease agent is brief and all cases develop within one incubation period.
  • In the epidemic curve, there is a sharp rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period and there are no secondary waves.
  • Infectious agents, environmental pollution and contamination of food are common causes of point epidemics.

questions.text: In a bimodal series, if the mean is 4 and median is 7, what is the mode?
questions.solution:
• The relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as Mode = 3 median – 2 mean.
  • In this scenario, mode = (3x7) – (2x4) = 21 – 8 = 13.

questions.text: Kuppuswamy scale considers all except
questions.solution:
The Kuppuswamy scale doesn’t include housing.

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: Which of the following is false about group discussion?

choices.text: It usually consists of 6 to 12 people
It can bring about change in attitude of the participants

questions.solution:
In a group discussion, 6-12 people with a group leader interact with each other in a face-to-face manner. Hence, option D is a false statement.

  • Exchange of ideas, knowledge, and opinions is done by participants which influence a change in their attitudes.
  • It usually involves 6–12 people with a group leader who guides the conversation giving equal opportunity to everyone to voice themselves.
  • In a group discussion, everyone must speak and be open to criticism without interruption.
  • If the group discussion goes well, it can help in arriving at finding solutions that would have not been possible to find for a single person.
  • Limitation – not everyone is open to speaking in public and the possibility of diversion of the topic of discussion is high when many people are involved.

questions.text: Forest plots are used to plot the results of ______
questions.solution:
A forest plot is used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: Pyrethrum, an insecticide, acts as a?
questions.solution: The Insecticide Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison.

questions.text: Exposure to sound with a minimum level of _______ dB can lead to rupture of tympanic membrane, resulting in hearing loss
questions.solution:
Exposure to sound with a minimum level of 160 dB can lead to rupture of tympanic membrane, resulting in hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following variables is measured on the nominal scale?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the A, B, O blood groups can be measured on a nominal scale.

Data will always fall into one of the following four scales:

  • Nominal
  • Ordinal
  • Interval
  • Ratio

Nominal scale data can be divided into qualitative categories or groups. Examples include male/female, black/white, or red/green. No order or ratio from the data is implied. Nominal data that falls exclusively into two groups is known as dichotomous data. A, B, O blood groups can be clearly divided into qualitative groups and hence can be measured on a nominal scale.

Ordinal scale data holds meaning when it is placed in a particular order. An example is the ranking of students in a class. But, there is no information about the interval size. This means that the difference between the marks of the first and second students may or may not be the same as the difference between the second and third. An example is the Glasgow coma scale and Child-Pugh score.

Interval scale data is similar to ordinal data because it can be placed in a meaningful order. Additionally, they have meaningful intervals between the items, usually measurable quantities. For example, the difference between 100° and 90° is the same as that between 50° and 40° on the temperature scale. But these scales do not have absolute zeroes, which makes ratios between the items meaningless. 

Ratio scale data have similar properties to interval scale data. In addition, they have an absolute zero. Most biomedical variables can be measured on a ratio scale. Examples are weight in pounds or grams, pulse rate in beats/minute, and blood pressure in millimeters of mercury. A pulse rate of 0 indicates a lack of pulse, and a rate of 120/minute is twice as fast as a rate of 60/minute. This means it is possible to calculate meaningful ratios. 

Other options:

Option B: Glasgow coma scale can be measured on the ordinal scale.

Option C: Intelligence quotient can be measured on the interval scale.

Option D: Respiratory rate can be measured with the ratio scale.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: At which level of heat stress index is a threat to health posed with work being impaired?
questions.solution:
A heat stress index of 40 – 60 indicates severe heat strain and it can pose a threat to health. Work is greatly impaired if not fit or acclimatized.

Heat Stress:

  • Heat stress is the load of heat that must be dissipated from the body if it is to remain in thermal equilibrium.
  • Factors which affect heat stress are metabolic rate, air temperature, humidity, air movement and radiant temperature.
  • Heat stress indices:
    • Equatorial comfort index
    • Heat stress index (HSI) – Values of HIS are as given below
HSI Thermal stress Work and effects
0 No thermal strain No work impairment
10 – 30 Moderate to mild heat strain Minimal work impairment
40 – 60 Severe heat strain Threat to health and greatly impaired work
70 – 90 Very severe heat strain Only few who are fit and acclimatized can sustain work
100 Upper limit of heat tolerance Only fit and acclimatized can sustain work, although with impairment
>100 Exceeds tolerable limits Varying degrees of heat stress and effects can pursue
  • Predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR)
    • Effects of heat stress include heat stroke, heat hyperpyrexia, heat exhaustion, heat cramps, and heat syncope

questions.text: False statement about the type of study depicted in below given image is:
questions.solution:
Incidence cannot be calculated from case control studies and can be done from longitudinal studies.

Option a: Attrition refers to loss of follow up. Since this is a backward looking study i.e. proceeds from effect to cause, follow up is not done and hence attrition is absent.

Option b: Case control study is suitable for rare diseases.

Option d: It is less time consuming since long term follow up is not needed.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: The following type of representation of data is used for what kind of variables?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a histogram that is used to represent frequency distributions of continuous quantitative data.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method for management based on behavioral sciences?
questions.solution:
Decision making is a quantitative method of management.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organisational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: Definition of population attributable risk is

choices.text: Extent to which disease can be attributed to risk factor under study
Estimate of amount of disease that can be reduced if risk factor is modified or eliminated
Risk of disease among exposed as compared to non exposed
Difference in risk of exposed and non exposed groups

questions.solution:
An estimate of the amount by which the disease could be reduced in that population if the suspected factor was eliminated or modified is given by population attributable risk.

It is defined as incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor.

Option a: Attributable risk indicates to what extent the disease under study can be attributed to the exposure.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and nonexposed group.

Attributable risk= (Incidence among exposed-incidence among non exposed)/(Incidence among exposed) × 100

Option c: Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. It is a direct measure (or index) of the "strength" of the association between suspected cause and effect.

Relative risk= (Incidence among exposed)/(Incidence among non exposed)

questions.text: Temporary hardness of water is primarily due to presence of
questions.solution:
Temporary hardness of water is primarily due to the presence of calcium and magnesium bicarbonates.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: In a population of 6000, new cases of TB are 500, and old cases are 150. What is the prevalence of TB in this case?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, old and new cases must be taken together as 650 total cases, thus making the prevalence of TB at 11%.

Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100

  • New cases of TB = 500
  • Old cases of TB = 150
  • Total population at that time = 6000

Hence,

  • Prevalence = (500+150) /6000 x 100 = 10.83% ⇒ 11%

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Social psychology is
questions.solution: Social psychology is defined as “the science of behaviour of individual in the society.”

questions.text: Disease not transmitted by mosquito shown in below given image is
questions.solution:
Image shows Aedes aegypti mosquito/tiger mosquito/black mosquito – black body with white stripes, wings are unspotted.

It acts as a vector for transmission of dengue, chikungunya, rift valley fever.

West Nile fever & Filariasis is transmitted by culex mosquito.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Single blind study means

choices.text: Interpreter or analyzer is blind about study
Only person being observed is aware of study

questions.solution:
In single blind trial, the trial is so planned that the participant is not aware whether he belongs to the study group or control group.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types:
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: False statement is

choices.text: RCT is the best study design to prove causation
Cross sectional study is the weakest study design to prove cause effect relationship.
Matching is done to ensure that suspected aetiological factor or the variable we wish to measure is matched

questions.solution:
• Matching is defined as the process by which we select controls in such a way that they are similar to cases with regard to certain pertinent selected variables (e.g., age) which are known to influence the outcome of disease and which, if not adequately matched for comparability, could distort or confound the results.
  • While matching it should be borne in mind that the suspected aetiological factor or the variable we wish to measure should not be matched, because by matching, its aetiological role is eliminated in that study.
  • The cases and controls will then become automatically alike with respect to that factor.

RCT is the best study design to prove causation (option a) and Cross sectional study is the weakest study design to prove cause effect relationship.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of cyclo-propagative transmission of disease
questions.solution:
Malaria is an example of cyclo-propagative transmission because it undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in mosquitoes.

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: Process of “Complete extension” in a family cycle refers to time period between

choices.text: Marriage and birth of first child
Birth of first child and birth of last child
Birth of last child and first child leaving home
First child leaving home and last child leaving parental home

questions.solution:
Complete extension in family cycle refers to time period between birth of last child and first child leaving home.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: Which of the following is a measure of position?
questions.solution:
Percentile is a measure of position.

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure
questions.solution:
Image shows globe thermometer which is used to measure mean radiant temperature.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text:
Match the following with their definitions
A.	Generation time	I.	Gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case 
B.	Serial interval	II.	Time during which an infectious agent may be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected person to another person
C.	Latent period	III.	Interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host
D.	Communicable period	IV.	Period from disease initiation to disease detection
questions.solution:
Generation time is defined as "the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host”.

Serial interval is defined as the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case.

The communicable period is defined as "the time during which an infectious agent may be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected person to another person, from an infected animal to man, or from an infected person to an animal, including arthropods".

The term latent period is used in noninfectious diseases as the equivalent of incubation period in infectious diseases. It has been defined as "the period from disease initiation to disease detection".

questions.text: The mean cholesterol levels are measured in patients before and after using an interventional drug. The statistical test of significance applied is _____
questions.solution:
In this scenario, a paired t-test would be used as the effect of a drug to change the cholesterol level is measured on the same sample before and after administration of the drug.

 

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Socratic method of communication includes
questions.solution:
• Socratic methods are methods of two-way communication.
  • Examples include symposium, panel discussions, and workshops.
  • Advantage: Learning is more active and the audience can participate by asking questions, etc.
  • It is able to influence human behaviour.

Lecture, television and films are one-way/didactic method of communication.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines cannot be used?
questions.solution:
Bottle C: The inner square is the same shade as the outer circle. Thus, it cannot be used.

Bottle D: The inner square is darker than the outer circle. Thus, it cannot be used.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A measure of position that divides the distribution into the ratio of 1:3 is the _____
questions.solution:
In quartiles, the first quartile Q1 divides the distribution into the ratio of 1:3, the second quartile Q2 divides it in the ratio of 1:1, and the third quartile Q3 divides it into the ratio of 3:1.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide it into equal groups.

  • They are also referred to as fractiles.
  • Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.
  • The median is also considered a quantile as it divides a distribution into two equal parts. The median is also the same as the 50th percentile and second quartile.

Types of quantiles:

  1. Tertiles divide a distribution into 3 equal groups
  2. Quartiles divide it into 4 equal parts or quarters
  3. Quintiles divide a distribution into 5 equal groups
  4. Deciles divide a distribution into 10 equal parts
  5. Vigintiles divide it into 20 equal groups
  6. Centiles:
  • They are also called percentiles and are commonly used, especially for ranking marks in an exam.
  • They divide a distribution into 100 equal parts. Here, the median is the same as the 50th percentile.
  • The formula to arrive at the rank order of a value is R = P/100 x (n + 1), where R is the rank of the desired observation, P is the percentile desired and n is the number of variables in the data.

questions.text: Identify the critical path
questions.solution:
Longest path of the network is called critical path.

  • Option A is the longest path (2+3+3+3+1= 12 days).
  • Option b = 2+2+2+2+1 = 9 days
  • Option c = 2+4+4+1 = 11 days

A delay in the critical path will cause delay in the entire project.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: Learned behaviour which is socially acquired is known as
questions.solution:
Culture is defined as “Learned behaviour which has been socially acquired.”

Option b: Acculturation refers to “culture contact” i.e. diffusion of culture when there is contact between two people with different types of culture. Cultural contact takes place via various ways such as trade and commerce, industrialization, propagation of religion, education and conquest.

Option c: Customs are the established patterns of behaviour that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting. It can be divided into 2 forms – folkway and mores.

Option d: Socialization is defined as a process by which man acquires beliefs, customs, traditions and prejudices of the society as a result of his everyday interaction with people of the society.

questions.text: Which of the following is false?

choices.text: Shrivastav committee – Creation of health guides
Kartar Singh committee – Multipurpose worker scheme
Jungalwalla committee – Integration of health services

questions.solution:
• Shrivastav committee recommended village health guide system.
  • Kartar singh committee recommended multipurpose worker scheme.
  • Jungalwalla committee recommended integration of health services.

Related Pearl: Health Planning Committees of India

Year

Name

Concepts and Programmes

1946

Bhore committee
  • Also called Health Survey and Development Committee
  • 1 PHC for 40,000 population
  • 3 million plan
  • 3 months training in PSM for physicians
  • Preventive and curative services at all administrative levels 

1962

Mudaliar committee
  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee
  • District hospitals to have specialists
  • 1 PHC for not more than 40,000 people
  • Constitution of All India Health Service

1963

Chadah committee
  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme
  • One basic health worker for 10,000 population 

1965

Mukerji committee
  • Delinked malaria activities from family planning activities.
  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

1966

Mukerji committee
  • Also called committee of Health Secretaries.
  • Detailed the Basic Health Service to be given at block level 

1967

Jungalwalla committee
  • Also called Committee on Integration of Health Services
  • Ban of private practice by government doctors
  • Equal pay for equal work and special pay for specialized work

1973

Kartar Singh committee
  • Also called Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning
  • Recommended male and female health workers
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

1975

Shrivastav committee
  • Also called Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower
  • Referral Services Complex
  • Rural Health Infrastructure of Sub centre, PHC and CHC
  • ROME scheme – Reorientation of health education
  • Establishment of Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Village Health Guide scheme
  • Bands of semi–professional and Para-professional Health workers 

1983

Krishnan committee

 
  • Urban Revamping Scheme
  • Integration of PHC       

1986

Bajaj committee
  • Formulation of National Medical and Health Education Policy.
  • Formulation of National Manpower Policy.
  • Health Manpower cells
  • Education commission.

questions.text: False about septic tank represented in below-given image is

choices.text: Aerobic oxidation takes place outside the tank

questions.solution:
• Ideal retention period for a septic tank is 24 hours.
  • If the retention period is too small, there is insufficient treatment of sewage and if it is too long, then undue septicity results.

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

Below is an image of a double-chambered septic tank.

questions.text: Strain used in mumps vaccine is
questions.solution:
Widely-used live attenuated mumps vaccine strains include the Jeryl Lynn, RIT 4385, Leningrad-3, L-Zagreb and Urabe strains.

Option a: Edmonston strain is used for preparation of measles vaccine.

Option c: "Danish 1331" strain is the WHO recommended strain for the production of BCG vaccine.

Option d: OKA strain is the strain used for Varicella zoster vaccine.

questions.text: Thickness of lead apron to prevent radiation
questions.solution: Thickness of lead apron is 0.5mm. They will reduce the intensity of scattered X-rays over 90% and shud be worn by all workers regularly associated with X-ray procedures.

questions.text: Which article of the Indian Constitution confers ‘Right to life’ to the citizens of India?
questions.solution:
The "Right to Life" is given in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.

Article 11: Parliament to regulate the rights of citizenship by law.

Article 12: According to it, the term ‘State’ denotes the union and state governments, the Parliament and state legislatures and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Indian government.

Article 22: Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted to the ICU due to a road traffic accident later developed pneumonia. What time duration is required to declare it to be a hospital-acquired infection?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, any infection occurring more than 48 hours after admission is usually considered a hospital-acquired infection. 

A hospital-acquired infection is defined as an infection acquired during hospital care that is not present or incubating at admission. It is acquired due to cross-infection of a patient by other patients, hospital staff. It is a determinant of the poor quality of service provided by the hospital. It is also called nosocomial infections.

The criteria for surveillance of nosocomial respiratory infections are:

  1. Cough
  2. Purulent sputum
  3. New infiltrate on radiograph consistent with infection

If any 2 of the above given 3 clinical features are present, a diagnosis of hospital-acquired respiratory infection is made.

questions.text: What is the distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes?
questions.solution: The distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes is 400 metres. This helps in limiting the spread of vector-borne diseases to new geographic regions.

questions.text: The method used for comparison of a new test and a gold standard test is ______
questions.solution:
The Bland-Altmann analysis is used for comparing a new method of measurement with another one, which usually is the gold standard.

  • This method involves the graphical construction of a Bland-Altmann plot which is used to compare the measurements from both methods.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to obtain consensus forecasts among a large number of people?
questions.solution:
Delphi method is a systematic interactive forecasting method, which is used to obtain a consensus forecast among a large number of people. It determines the degree of agreement on a topic.

This can help in setting priorities or selecting alternatives in planning. This method uses questionnaires, which are answered by experts in two or more rounds.
